title: Positive toric fibrations
summary:
A principal toric bundle $M$ is a complex manifold equipped with a free
holomorphic action of a compact complex torus $T$. Such a manifold is fibered
over $M/T$, with fiber $T$. We discuss the notion of positivity in fiber
bundles and define positive toric bundles. Given an irreducible complex
subvariety $X\subset M$ of a positive principal toric bundle, we show that
either $X$ is $T$-invariant, or it lies in an orbit of $T$-action. For
principal elliptic bundles, this theorem is known (math.AG/0403430). As follows
from Borel-Remmert-Tits theorem, any compact simply connected homogeneous
complex manifold is a principal toric bundle. We show that compact Lie groups
with left-invariant complex structure $I$ are positive toric bundles, if $I$ is
generic. Other examples of positive toric bundles are discussed.

Abstract
A principal toric bundle M is a complex manifold equipped

T . Such a manifold is fibered over M/T , with fiber T . We

show that either X is T -invariant, or it lies in an orbit

M. Verbitsky, March 6, 2007

Introduction
Principal toric bundles were always a source of examples in complex geometry (classical Hopf manifolds and Calabi-Eckmann spaces come to mind), but
the recent progress in string theory in interaction with algebraic geometry
puts a new light on this classical subject. Since a discovery of the hypercomplex structures on compact Lie groups and other homogeneous spaces
by the physicists Spindel et al ([SSTV]) and then Joyce ([J]), the complex
geometry of homogeneous spaces became a focus of much research, being
a target space of supersymmetric string theories with rich supersymmetry.
However, the algebraic geometry of these spaces is not much understood.
This paper is an attempt to fill this gap, bringing a number of results about
subvarieties of principal toric bundles, in particular - compact homogeneous
compex manifolds with abelian fundamental group.
A principal toric bundle M is a complex manifold equipped with a free
holomorphic action of a compact complex torus T . Such a manifold is fibered
over M/T , with fiber T . In the sequel, we discuss positivity in fiber bundles
and define positive toric bundles, generalizing a notion developed for elliptic
bundles in [V].
Many examples of principal toric bundles appear from a theory of complex homogeneous manifolds. It is known since 1960-es that a simply connected compact complex homogeneous manifold is a principal toric fibration
over a rational projective homogeneous manifold (this is known as the Tits
fibration). In fact, this result holds for a complex homogeneous manifold
with abelian fundamental group (Theorem 2.3).
A principal toric fibration obtained this way from a general complex
structure on a Lie group is always positive (Theorem 2.7).
We study complex subvarieties of positive principal toric fibrations. Given
an irreducible complex subvariety X ⊂ M of a positive principal toric bundle, we show that either X is T -invariant, or it lies in an orbit of T -action
(Theorem 1.13).
This theorem is elementary for dimC T = 1, but for dimC T > 1 the
proof uses highly non-trivial results on deformation theory and the spaces
of Fujiki class C, which are due to Fujiki and Demailly-Paun.

Convexity and positivity

For the purposes of the present paper, a good notion of positivity in fiber
bundles would give the same consequences as in Theorem 1.3. All irreducible
π
subvarieties of a positive fiber bundle M −→ X should lie in the fiber or
have the form π −1 (Z); and all stable bundles must be pullbacks, up to
tensoring with a line bundle.
Further on in this paper, we study principal toric fibrations, that is,
fibrations with a fiber which is a compact complex torus. They are defined
in the same way as principal elliptic fibrations.
Definition 1.4: Let T be a compact complex torus. A principal toric
fibration, or a principal toric bundle with a fiber T is a complex manifold
M equipped with a free holomorphic action of T . We consider a principal
π
toric fibration as a T -fibration M −→ M/T .
Principal toric fibrations appear in different disguises in all kinds of
algebro-geometric research. A classification of these objects is found in [Hö].
Even for principal toric fibrations, it is not clear what is a good notion
of positivity. One could require that π ∗ ω is exact, for some Kähler form ω
on X. This is clearly not enough. Indeed, one could take a positive elliptic
fibration, and its product with a torus T1 , as a toric fibration. The pullback
π ∗ ω is exact. However, any subvariety of X × T1 (and there could be many)
gives a corresponding subvariety of M .
Still, this notion has useful geometric consequences.

2.1

Homogeneous complex manifolds
Homogeneous complex manifolds and toric fibrations

This paper appeared as an attempt to understand the algebraic geometry of
compact, homogeneous, simply connected manifolds. These manifolds were
classicied by H. C. Wang ([Wa]) and much studied during 1950-ies and the
1960-ies. H. Samelson ([Sa]) discovered homogeneous complex structures
on even-dimensional semisimple Lie groups. In 1980-es and 1990-ies the
Samelson manifolds became more and more important in string physics,
differential geometry and algebraic geometry.
Ever since the physicists Spindel et al ([SSTV]) and then Joyce ([J])
constructed homogeneous hypercomplex structures on some compact Lie
groups, generalizing Samelson's work, these manifolds became a favourite
testbed for all kinds of conjectures and constructions in quaternionic geometry and sometimes in physics (see e.g. [OP]). In addition, these manifolds
are examples of two rather unique (and mysteriously related) geometries,
which arose in string theory. The Joyce's hypercomplex manifolds are the
only known in dimension > 4 examples of so-called strong HKT geometry
([HP], [GP]). In addition, these manifolds are among the few compact examples of generalized Kähler manifolds (known in physics as manifolds with
(2,2)-supersymmetry); see [GHR], [Hi]. Combining these two structures,
one obtains an even more mysterious (and rare) geometry, called generalized
hyperkähler geometry, or (4,4)-supersymmetry ([GHR], [Br], [MV]), which
also occurs on Joyce's hypercomplex manifolds.
From their construction, which is explained in Subsection 2.3, it is clear
that the Samelson manifolds are fibered over a flag space, with fibers being compact tori. It is a special case of a general result due to Borel and
Remmert ([BR]) and Tits ([T]), and its generalization, proven in this paper
(Theorem 2.3); see also [GR].
Theorem 2.1: Let M be a compact, homogeneous, simply connected complex manifold. Then M is a principal toric fibration over a base X, which
is a homogeneous, rational, projective manifold.

Quite often, a compact, homogeneous complex manifold would have
H 2 (M, Q) = 0. The Calabi-Eckmann manifolds and the Hopf manifolds
we mentioned previously clearly satisfy H 2 (M ) = 0. Let G be a compact
Lie group with H 1 (G, Q) = 0. The cohomology algebra of G is a Hopf
algebra; by Hopf theorem ([Ho]), H ∗ (G, Q) is a free exterior algebra, with
generators of odd degree. In particular, H 2 (G, Q) = 0.
If G is even-dimensional, G admits a left-invariant complex structure;
if G is odd-dimensional, G × S 1 admits a left-invariant complex structure.
These manifolds are called Samelson spaces (see Subsection 2.4). In both
of these cases, H 2 (M, Q) = 0, and the corresponding principal toric bundle
(Theorem 2.3) is convex. If the torus T is, in addition, simple, M is Qpositive. Further on in this section, we explain that this happens for generic
complex structures on G and G × S 1 .

2.4

Samelson spaces

The left-invariant complex structures on Lie groups were constructed by H.
Samelson in 1954 ([Sa]).
Definition 2.6: Let G be an even-dimensional, compact, semisimple Lie
group, and I a left-invariant complex structure on G. Then (G, I) is called
a Samelson space. It is a homogeneous complex manifold.
Let G be an even-dimensional compact Lie group; it is obviously semisimple. Denote by GC its complexification, and let B ⊂ GC be its Borel subgroup, and F = GC /B the corresponding flag space, which is obviously
compact. The group G can be considered as a subgroup in GC ; the natural
projection G −→ F is surjective, and has the maximal torus of G as its fiber.
This is the toric fibration we require; it remains only to produce a complex
structure on G which is compatible with this fibration.
Denote by U the unipotent radical of B. The space M̃ := GC /U is fibered
over F with a fiber TC = (C∗ )k , with k = dimR G − 2 dimC F being even.
We arrive at the situation described at the end of Subsection 2.3: a (C∗ )2n fibration over a compact base. Taking a quotient of M̃ with a subgroup
V ⊂ TC = isomorphic to Cn , as indicated in Subsection 2.3, we obtain
a principal toric fibration M = M̃ /V . Embedding G into M̃ = GC /U ,
and projecting to M , we identify G with M , and this identification is by
construction G-invariant.
Clearly, this principal fibration is the one postulated by Borel-RemmertTits theorem (Theorem 2.1).
Notice that we have a complete freedom of choosing V ⊂ TC . Therefore the left-invariant complex structure on G can be chosen in such a way
that any given torus of appropriate dimension becomes a fiber of the Tits
fibration.

3.1

Varieties of Fujiki class C

Definition 3.1: Let X, Y be complex varieties, and C ⊂ X × Y a closed
subvariety, such that the projections C −→ X, C −→ Y are proper and
generically one-to-one. Such C is called a bimeromorphic morphism,
or bimeromorphic modification between X and Y .
Clearly, a composition of bimeromorphic maps is well defined, and is
again bimeromorphic.
Definition 3.2: Let M be a complex variety. We say that M is in Fujiki
class C if M is bimeromorphic to a Kähler manifold.
